summary: DETECTIVE PIKACHU MOVIE SEQUEL IN THE WORKS
title: DETECTIVE PIKACHU MOVIE SEQUEL IN THE WORKS
body: Detective Pikachu has been a hit both critically and commercially, so it only makes sense that a sequel would be in the pipeline. While Legendary has not confirmed the news publicly, multiple sources involved with production have anonymously confirmed that a sequel is being worked on. The movie is in the early stages of development right now, so we most likely won’t be hearing official details for quite some time.

reblog.comment: Detective Pikachu has been a hit both critically and commercially, so it only makes sense that a sequel would be in the pipeline. The movie is in the early stages of development right now, so we most likely won’t be hearing official details for quite some time.

title: Spoiler-Free Detective Pikachu review:
body:
Ryan Reynolds is literally in a fursuit the entire duration of the film. 


Also, more importantly:

I Am Ready To Lay My Life Down For Literally ANY Of The Pokemon In This Film!!!! 

Like forreal!!!!

I will DIE for these babies!!!!!!!!!!!!

Even if there’s no reason for me to die!!!!!! I’m Fricking Ready!!! ANY TIME!!!!!!!!

blog.name: aquilacalvitium
blog.title: Your Triple A Friend
blog.description:
No One Ever Made a Difference by Being Like Everybody Else ----------------------------------------------------------------
Aquila/Claire, Ace, Aro, Agender, 18yo (UK), furry, they/Them. Feel free to message me about whetever you eant at any time, even if we've never spoken before! Please refrain from any mention of drugs, suicide, self harm or any NSFW content. If you want to vent, I'm here to listen, but might not be much help if you want advice. Thanks for stopping by, have a great day!! ♡

summary:
Just watched Detective Pikachu!
Despite figuring out two major plot twists within the first thirty minutes it was really...
body:
Just watched Detective Pikachu!

Despite figuring out two major plot twists within the first thirty minutes it was really entertaining! I never really enjoyed Pokémon all that much when I was younger but this movie didn’t fail to keep me in the world of Pokémon and I enjoyed every moment of it. There wasn’t a moment I was disinterested 😊😊

reblog.comment:

There wasn’t a moment I was disinterested 😊😊

summary: Early on in the Detective Pikachu film, a particular character mentions Pokemon and humans living together in Rime City without...
body:
Early on in the Detective Pikachu film, a particular character mentions Pokemon and humans living together in Rime City without Trainers, without battles, living harmoniously.

I wonder if specifically calling it ‘harmonious’ after all that talk about how normal Pokemon/human relations are not ideal was meant as a tipoff to fans that something is off.

reblog.comment:

summary: 'FURROWED BROW' DETECTIVE PIKACHU STICKERS RELEASE IN JAPAN
title: 'FURROWED BROW' DETECTIVE PIKACHU STICKERS RELEASE IN JAPAN
body: Looks like Pokemon Co. has been paying attention to what Detective Pikachu fans are talking about. All sorts of fan-art for ‘Furrowed Brow’ Detective Pikachu followed the release of the first trailer, and now those fans can buy some official 'Furrowed Brow’ merch in the form of stickers. These are available at Pokemon Center/Store locations in Japan, and can be picked up for free by showing a Detective Pikachu movie stub to a cashier.

reblog.comment: Looks like Pokemon Co. has been paying attention to what Detective Pikachu fans are talking about. All sorts of fan-art for ‘Furrowed Brow’ Detective Pikachu followed the release of the first trailer, and now those fans can buy some official 'Furrowed Brow’ merch in the form of stickers. blog.name: delayedcritique
blog.title: Delayed Critique
blog.description: Where you can find all of my reviews

title: POKÉMON DETECTIVE PIKACHU REVIEW
body:
“An adorable PG Deadpool with a POKÉMON skin.”

Every popular kid’s property is destined to get a live action movie adaptation. It was only a matter of time until POKÉMON was made into a live action movie. With the massive popularity of the games and the nostalgia older fans have for the brand, the box office returns are already set before the film was even made. How much money a POKÉMON movie would make relies entirely on the quality of the story and the talent behind it.

POKÉMON DETECTIVE PIKACHU is the latest adaptation based on the worldwide phenomenon of the POKÉMON franchise. Unlike the majority of the mainstream video games or the favorite anime, this film installment has nothing to do with catching pokémon from the wild. Instead, this adaptation is retelling the story of the 2016 Nintendo 3DS game of the same name.

Enter the world of Ryme City; a society where human and pokémon can interact freely. After the death of his father, Tim Goodman (Justice Smith) must travel to Ryme City to collect his father’s belongings. Along the way, he comes across a mischievous Pikachu (Ryan Reynolds) where both of them can strangely understand each other. As each of them has a connection to Tim’s father, they set off on a detective adventure to uncover the truth about Henry Goodman’s disappearance.

The main attraction towards this movie is the incorporation of the cartoonish pokémon into the real world. For the most part, this integration is the most substantial element of the film. Even as a minimal fan of the brand, I was very impressed every time a new pokémon was brought on screen. Throughout the entire runtime, I was sucked into this world and believed that Pokémon was living among real-life people.

As the world building is solid, the performances are hit and miss. The three main characters to follow are Smith’s reluctant Tim, Reynold’s wise-cracking Detective Pikachu, and a young reporter by the name of Lucy Stevens (Kathryn Newton). Each one of these characters represents the three central performances from the entire cast; acting too subdue, going too over-the-top, and the appropriate mixture of fun and serious.

Smith’s central performance represents a lack of excitement and motivation. The character that’s meant to be the most identifiable for the audience to connect with ends up as being the least interesting out of the cast. No disrespect to the actor, but his character is beyond generic and uninteresting.

On the complete opposite end is Newton acting as a Saturday morning cartoon with her over-the-top performance. The moment she walks into the movie, she is acting like a stereotypical “kid-detective” character who’s overly energetic and confuses aggression over charm. Even as Newton is acting too strong with her character, it makes sense compared to the source material that had these types of characters.

Perfectly sandwiched in the middle is Reynolds’ perfect balance of being energetic and comedic and genuinely performing during the serious scenes. The best element of the entire film appropriately comes from Reynolds’ entertaining and believable portrayal of the cute, yet motivated Detective Pikachu. His addition to the cast is such a perfect choice to attract the casual POKÉMON fans to this movie that’s a fan letter to the dedicated followers.

For the massive POKÉMON fans, this is everything you dreamed about seeing on the big screen. There is so much to pick up and enjoy this movie. The brand is treated with respect and class that never insults the fanbase and their love for the series. Director Rob Letterman brought so much love and creativity to delivering the world of Pokémon to life.

However, no matter your viewpoint on the brand as a whole, everyone will agree that the story and writing are beyond lazy and predictable. Looking at this as a simple family friendly detective story, it is insultingly easy to guess every twist and turn that the story will reach. The predictability of the whole product is hugely distracting. The moment where I figured out the ending plot points early in the film, I was instantly disengaged as the story progresses towards its conclusion. While I was enjoying the effects and some of the performances, the story turned into a massive distraction when I figured out its destination.

POKÉMON DETECTIVE PIKACHU is an entertaining, yet very flawed video game movie. It’s not the film to revolutionize the cinematic genre, but it is a big step in the right direction. The effects of the pokémon and Reynolds’ performance were the standouts against the rest of the flawed and predictable elements. Aside from the painfully obvious reveal, nothing is insulting or harmful about this movie. This is definitely a movie directed closer for kids in mind than catering to its older audiences. As this is a must-see for kids and young teens, everyone older can catch this in the comfort of their homes.

6.5/10

Looking at this as a simple family friendly detective story, it is insultingly easy to guess every twist and turn that the story will reach. The predictability of the whole product is hugely distracting. The moment where I figured out the ending plot points early in the film, I was instantly disengaged as the story progresses towards its conclusion. While I was enjoying the effects and some of the performances, the story turned into a massive distraction when I figured out its destination.

POKÉMON DETECTIVE PIKACHU is an entertaining, yet very flawed video game movie. It’s not the film to revolutionize the cinematic genre, but it is a big step in the right direction. The effects of the pokémon and Reynolds’ performance were the standouts against the rest of the flawed and predictable elements. Aside from the painfully obvious reveal, nothing is insulting or harmful about this movie. This is definitely a movie directed closer for kids in mind than catering to its older audiences. As this is a must-see for kids and young teens, everyone older can catch this in the comfort of their homes.

6.5/10
trail.content:
“An adorable PG Deadpool with a POKÉMON skin.”

Every popular kid’s property is destined to get a live action movie adaptation. It was only a matter of time until POKÉMON was made into a live action movie. With the massive popularity of the games and the nostalgia older fans have for the brand, the box office returns are already set before the film was even made. How much money a POKÉMON movie would make relies entirely on the quality of the story and the talent behind it.

POKÉMON DETECTIVE PIKACHU is the latest adaptation based on the worldwide phenomenon of the POKÉMON franchise. Unlike the majority of the mainstream video games or the favorite anime, this film installment has nothing to do with catching pokémon from the wild. Instead, this adaptation is retelling the story of the 2016 Nintendo 3DS game of the same name.

Enter the world of Ryme City; a society where human and pokémon can interact freely. After the death of his father, Tim Goodman (Justice Smith) must travel to Ryme City to collect his father’s belongings. Along the way, he comes across a mischievous Pikachu (Ryan Reynolds) where both of them can strangely understand each other. As each of them has a connection to Tim’s father, they set off on a detective adventure to uncover the truth about Henry Goodman’s disappearance.

The main attraction towards this movie is the incorporation of the cartoonish pokémon into the real world. For the most part, this integration is the most substantial element of the film. Even as a minimal fan of the brand, I was very impressed every time a new pokémon was brought on screen. Throughout the entire runtime, I was sucked into this world and believed that Pokémon was living among real-life people.

As the world building is solid, the performances are hit and miss. The three main characters to follow are Smith’s reluctant Tim, Reynold’s wise-cracking Detective Pikachu, and a young reporter by the name of Lucy Stevens (Kathryn Newton). Each one of these characters represents the three central performances from the entire cast; acting too subdue, going too over-the-top, and the appropriate mixture of fun and serious.

Smith’s central performance represents a lack of excitement and motivation. The character that’s meant to be the most identifiable for the audience to connect with ends up as being the least interesting out of the cast. No disrespect to the actor, but his character is beyond generic and uninteresting.

On the complete opposite end is Newton acting as a Saturday morning cartoon with her over-the-top performance. The moment she walks into the movie, she is acting like a stereotypical “kid-detective” character who’s overly energetic and confuses aggression over charm. Even as Newton is acting too strong with her character, it makes sense compared to the source material that had these types of characters.

Perfectly sandwiched in the middle is Reynolds’ perfect balance of being energetic and comedic and genuinely performing during the serious scenes. The best element of the entire film appropriately comes from Reynolds’ entertaining and believable portrayal of the cute, yet motivated Detective Pikachu. His addition to the cast is such a perfect choice to attract the casual POKÉMON fans to this movie that’s a fan letter to the dedicated followers.

For the massive POKÉMON fans, this is everything you dreamed about seeing on the big screen. There is so much to pick up and enjoy this movie. The brand is treated with respect and class that never insults the fanbase and their love for the series. Director Rob Letterman brought so much love and creativity to delivering the world of Pokémon to life.

However, no matter your viewpoint on the brand as a whole, everyone will agree that the story and writing are beyond lazy and predictable. Looking at this as a simple family friendly detective story, it is insultingly easy to guess every twist and turn that the story will reach. The predictability of the whole product is hugely distracting. The moment where I figured out the ending plot points early in the film, I was instantly disengaged as the story progresses towards its conclusion. While I was enjoying the effects and some of the performances, the story turned into a massive distraction when I figured out its destination.

POKÉMON DETECTIVE PIKACHU is an entertaining, yet very flawed video game movie. It’s not the film to revolutionize the cinematic genre, but it is a big step in the right direction. The effects of the pokémon and Reynolds’ performance were the standouts against the rest of the flawed and predictable elements. Aside from the painfully obvious reveal, nothing is insulting or harmful about this movie. This is definitely a movie directed closer for kids in mind than catering to its older audiences. As this is a must-see for kids and young teens, everyone older can catch this in the comfort of their homes.

6.5/10
